sourceDesc.p:
This publication constitutes a remediation of the printed REED collections - Inns of Court, Ecclesiastical London, and Civic London to 1558. Information on original sources for transcriptions can be accessed via the Document Descriptions.
Ecclesiastical London
Mary C. Erler
University of Toronto Press and The British Library. 2008

Inns of Court

Civic London to 1558

projectDesc.p: Records of Early English Drama (REED) is an international scholarly project that is establishing for the first time the context from which the drama of Shakespeare and his contemporaries grew. Founded in 1976, REED has worked since then to locate, transcribe, and edit historical documents containing evidence of drama, secular music, and other communal entertainment and ceremony from the Middle Ages until 1642, when the Puritans closed the London theatres.

REED London Online is a prototype online collection developing from the Records of Early English Drama (REED) in partnership with the Canadian Writing Research Collaboratory (CWRC) and supported by Bucknell University. It aims to establish an openly accessible online scholarly and pedagogical resource of London-centric documentary, editorial, and bibliographic materials related to performance, theatre, and music spanning the period 1100-1642. With support from an NHPRC-Mellon Planning Grant for Digital Edition Publishing Cooperatives and CANARIE Research Software Program grants, REED London is creating new environments for scholarly presentation of archival materials gathered from legal, ecclesiastical, civic, political, and personal archival sources in and around London. The objective of the REED London project team is to build a stable, extensible publication environment that optimizes access to these compiled materials in ways that respond to scholars’ research interests across disciplines. Consulting with other planning grant recipients will be invaluable to ensuring that REED London’s production and publication environment is in line with standards laid out in the NHPRC-Mellon grant objectives. It is hoped that the progress REED London and CWRC make will also inform the larger dialogue about best practices among funded teams.

Court of Common Councill, [ournal 10 MA: COL/CC/o1/o1/o1
ff 238-8
lsto die constitutur per Maiorem & Aldermannos quod die Aduentus domine
katterine fillie Regis lspanie in Ciuitatem Maior ett Aldermanni tempore
pertransitus eiusdem domine sedebunt Equestres in locis suis consuetis &
convenientihus in le Chepe ex australi parte Et quod pre eis ponatur vna
Raile asserata vocata boredid in defencione Equorum
ltem ad eandem Curiam concessum est quod quiliet Aldermannus haheat tune
eodem die Bedellum suum portantem Clauam suam & tantum vnum alium
seruientem attendenter super eum
Et quod Gardiani pontis londonij erga aduentum predictum Gravellabunt
pontem londonij ett [le] pistenarij le ffisshe strete ac Camerarius londonij
Stratam de Chepe a [le] magno Conductu ad paruum Conductum
Et quod dicus Camerarius prouidebit pro vno Garnyssh de vasis argenteis vell
magnis ollis argenteis vel fflagons dandis predice domine &c.
Et quod fiat cuilihet Aldermanno vnum preceptum in hec verba We charge
and commaund you that on Monday next commyng
ff 250v-(12 April)
To the Right honorable lord and worshipfull Soueraignes the Maire and
aldermen of bis noble Cittee of london
Shewith full humbly vnto your good lordship [your] and Mastershippes your
daily oratours and seruauntes lohn Marchall lohn Broun william Pallyng
Nicholas Ryppes And lohn Nayler waytes of the forsaid noble Cittee That
where of tyme out of mynde it hath been wont and accustumed in the
same noble Cittee, that waytes by reason of their seruice shuld be reputed
and taken as ffremen of the said Cittee lt is soo Right honorable lord and
worshipfull soueraignes that the felasshippe of Mynsterelx fremen of the
same Cittee wull not suffre your said oratours to occupie and bye and selle

preceptum
Aldermannis

9/ lsto die: 4 No₻ember
10/ die ... Ciuitate entry of Tatherine of Aragon 12 Noyember 150
23/ Monday ... commyng: Monday, 8 Noember
1m] Minstrelles, Mord obscured by tear in leaf and modern repair

within the said Cittee onlesse they be admytted fremen of the said Cittee in
the Craft of Mynstrelx And your said oratours be not [able] of Abylite and
power in | goodes to bye their fredom Soo that if your said lordship and
Mastershippes be not tenderly shewed vnto theym they must nedes provyde
for their lyvynges in other places out of this noble Cittee lt may therfore plese
your good lordshippe and Mastershippes of your blessed dissposicions the
premisses by you tenderly considered to graunt and ordeign that your said
oratours may be admitted fremen of london in the Craft of Mynstrelles
without any charge to theym to be leyde for their fredom And ouer that to
graunt and ordeign that the same your oratours may haue their sommer
Clothing like as it was promysed vnto theym att theire commyng to london
And your said oratours all the dayes of theire lyves shalbe your true bedemen
And specially pray to god for the preseruacion of your good lordshippe &
mastershippes and the Comonaltie of this Cittee long to indure &c.
Qua quidem billa &c.

[At this courte it is agreed that Mr Milbourne chamberlen shall macke a lees
to willyam Strynger [ins] in consideracion And [rew] for recompense and
reward of the labour that the same willyam haith Susteynid and tayn aswell
a boute the Rekynnyng of the Stuff that was occupied aboute the pageantes
as a boute the Nwe woorkes made att the gyldhall of]

Att this courte it is agreed that in consideracion and for recompense and
rewarde [that] of the labours and dilligence that willyam Strynger haith
susteynyd and tane aswell a boute the rekennynges of the stuff and charges
don vppon the pageantes made a gaynst my lady princes first enteryng in to
this cite as a boute the howses of offices nwe made att the gyldhall/ [(.)]
willyam Milbourne chamberlen shall macke to the saide willyam Strynger A
lees of the howse that he nowe dwellyth yn wich howse willyam ffox Clerk
of the Maires courte late occupied and helde [for] in the parisshe of sceynt
Michaell in Bassynghawe for the space of xx yeres paiyng and yeldyng to the
chamber for the same yerly/ v s./ duryng the saide terme of xx yeres/

Court of Aldermen, Repertory I TMA: CL/CA/o1/o/0o
f 130 27March)
lt is agreed that att the solempnisacion of the leage made betwene the
kynges grace and the kyng of Romaynes And makyng of the kynges oithe in is
conformacion of the same theire shalbe ffires made of fagottes in ix places of
this Cite that is to Saye on att ledenhall/ a nother att the stander in Cornehull/
[a] iiij in chepe (at the greate cundite standard And litill Cundite) and on
in ffletestrete And att every place where as fire shalbe there shalbe a hoggishede
of wyne/ And iij sereauntes and ij yomen of the Shryves for kepyng of the
peace and orderyng of the people
ltem it is agreed that through oute Cornehull And Chepe side, on boith sides
of the streate theire shalbee hanggid oute of wyndowes Cressettes with light
to beegynne att vj of the Clock att nygtht and to byrne the space of A howre/
And the [fr] fyres to beegyn att iiij of the clock att afternone
ltem it is throught that in consideracion of the holy tyme of lent and also of
the late departyng from this lyfe of the most noble prynces [que] Elizabeth
late queene to our soueren lorde the kyng that all Mynstralsie shalbe sparyd
att this solempnite &c.

35/ Cristopher Eliot and Edward ffenkill: Bridge ardens 14001500

The whiche Cxxij li. viiij s. v d. been allowed to the said Cristopher and
Edward the xixth day of Septembre the xixth yere of king Henry the vijth, by
the Maire and Aldermen as in money expendyd and paid for the new making
of a pagente sett vpon london bridge in thentre of the lady princes of Spayne
And as of record in the Courte of the said Maire and Aldermen plainely doth
appere & sic summa illa
